articleContent.title: Chord: Minor 7th in F# (Shape: G)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: Minor 7th in F# (Shape: G)

## Brief Presentation
The F# minor 7th chord, played in the shape of a G chord on the guitar, consists of four notes - F# (root), A (minor third), C# (perfect fifth), and E (minor seventh). This chord has a melancholic and mellow quality due to the minor tonality and the dissonance created by the minor 7th interval.

## Notes and Intervals
- F# (Root)
- A (Minor 3rd)
- C# (Perfect 5th)
- E (Minor 7th)

The intervals in this chord are:
- Root to Minor 3rd (A): 3 semitones
- Root to Perfect 5th (C#): 7 semitones
- Root to Minor 7th (E): 10 semitones

## Genre and Flavor
The F# minor 7th chord, with its somber and jazzy sound, is commonly used in genres like jazz, blues, R&B, and funk. It adds depth and emotion to chord progressions and melodies, creating a sophisticated and soulful vibe in the music.

## Songs
Here are three songs that prominently use the F# minor 7th chord:
1. "Fly Me to the Moon" by Frank Sinatra
2. "Ain't No Sunshine" by Bill Withers
3. "So What" by Miles Davis

These songs showcase the versatility and emotional impact of the F# minor 7th chord in various musical contexts.
